body:
I'm concerned it might happen. History has proven with reddit and Digg that it usually does.

The admins are already repeatedly reaching out to the same few users (who aren't admins) to help them with their work (including moderating official Ruqqus stuff), but not even telling anyone else about it. This will always happen to some degree, but when some people are given more authority over the official site that's when it needs to stop. These positions need to be open for everyone to apply or strictly limited to admins, otherwise it's corrupt and unfair to everyone else. And on top of that it *will* eventually lead to a Reddit/Digg-like cabal. I don't believe the admins do this intentionally, as nepotism is natural. I'm sure I'm plenty guilty myself, so I don't hold anything against the admins, but they need to more closely watch how they decide who to recruit for these roles. I call them "modmins" because they aren't admins but the admins have made them kind of "moderators" of Ruqqus itself. Simply limiting how many guilds you can mod won't magically stop power user cabals from forming, I think that might actually make matters worse because it makes it much more difficult for someone to foster their own guilds.

This is not causing issues right now, and all of these users are extremely trustworthy imo. But over time these cliques tend to become more and more prideful, and at the point when they see themselves as greater than everyone else that's when they begin to justify censorship in their minds.

body:
My issue isn't that people posting things like "gas the jews" triggers me, it's that it's low effort and there are people posting it over and over on topics unrelated to it. If someone want to make a serious post about how they think the holocaust is fake or reasons they hate Jews by all means do so, just don't lazily spam curse words that I have to sort through to find actual content and ideas.

 I want a place where I can have actual discussions instead of just a circle jerk of copy pasting the same crap. I didn't leave a left wing propaganda site because I wanted a right wing propaganda site, I would've just went to voat.

body:
It works as long as there aren't too many. Problem is that people can copy paste the same comment 100 times with the same effort of 1 person providing real content. It's like chat rooms on Youtube, often when there's a rocket launch live stream there's are 100s of comments a minute spamming flat earth stuff which makes it impossible to read anything else. It's one of the risks of having 0 moderation.

I'm not saying it's like that here but it's a risk as the site grows.

body: At the moment it's not censoring, but there are a few users that the admins are giving authority to, and they are not even telling anyone else about these positions. One example is moderating the official Ruqqus discord. That's definitely not a good idea, and it's the same one that led to the formation of a power user cabal on reddit and Digg, which will inevitably lead to censorship. I trust them all at the moment, but even still it's not being fair to the rest of the Ruqqus userbase. These roles of helping the admins run Ruqqus need to be open for everyone or strictly limited to admins only.

body:
I am also a "Reddit refugee" and I did delete my Reddit account and all my comments and posts. So long as Ruqqus retains this clause in their terms:
>Ruqqus reserves the right to remove content that we deem to violate content policy or the terms of service, and to deactivate accounts responsible for such violations.
https://ruqqus.com/help/terms

Then they can still fall into censorship. To be honest, I'm content to use Ruqqus with that clause until they start going the route of Reddit. Maybe then I'll look for an actually distributed, censorship-resistant solution. Until then, I'm content to use the centralized service.

body:
It's an endless cycle, I've just learned to accept it at this point. Reddit will become so PC that it will become boring. People will slowly migrate to other platforms that are more interesting, have more diverse views, etc. Once those people make up the majority of their new home, they call for censorship, etc. And then the cycle repeats. 

You see the same thing with voters, e.g. Californians moving to Texas because it has a better economy and cheaper costs of living, they move from blue states with anti-middle class laws to red states, but then vote to turn their new home blue. It's madness, but it is what it is. 

Easier to just accept it and just always stay one step ahead of the curve.
body_html:
It's an endless cycle, I've just learned to accept it at this point. Reddit will become so PC that it will become boring. People will slowly migrate to other platforms that are more interesting, have more diverse views, etc. Once those people make up the majority of their new home, they call for censorship, etc. And then the cycle repeats.

You see the same thing with voters, e.g. Californians moving to Texas because it has a better economy and cheaper costs of living, they move from blue states with anti-middle class laws to red states, but then vote to turn their new home blue. It's madness, but it is what it is.

Easier to just accept it and just always stay one step ahead of the curve.

body:
Censorship and limitations are inevitable as a platform grows. Reddit was the same way when it first started, with many people calling it the free speech alternative to Digg when that started going under. The same thing will happen to Ruqqus if it achieves mainstream popularity, and whatever comes after that, and so on and so forth, probably for as long as the internet is a thing and human beings are capable of diverse thoughts and the desire to express them. 

Whatever happens, it'll be fine, because when one social media platform starts sagging, several more sprout up to take its place. It's nature.

body:
You need that, you need to quit giving the same two users admin-tier jobs without offering them to anyone else, and you need to move the official Ruqqus discussion channels off of Discord. The last two are the biggest issues for me right now.

As for Discord, it's not the most accessible platform. I miss a lot that Ruqqus has to offer because I can't use Discord anymore. It makes you link your account to a phone number now, and a lot of people are unfairly banned from Discord because of corrupt employees like allthefoxes (who is also a member of DefaultMods).

I think I've discovered a phenomenon that we should call CrystalVulpine's Law: Any organization which does not explicitly oppose domination by cabals or cliques will become controlled by one over time. I've observed it running rampant in almost every single power structure, and the reason is because nepotism is very natural to people and it's not something you set out to do or realize you're doing. Even I'm guilty of it, and I'm the one whose been ranting about DefaultMods non-stop for over two years now. The trick is that you have to be careful you're not handing out positions of authority or special treatment because you're friends with the person. The process needs to be the same for everyone. Otherwise you're treating your users unfairly, and over time the circle of people who are in control will become prideful of their positions, and when they reach the point of thinking they are above others then censorship and rule will be justified in their minds.

parent.body:
My issue isn't that people posting things like "gas the jews" triggers me, it's that it's low effort and there are people posting it over and over on topics unrelated to it. If someone want to make a serious post about how they think the holocaust is fake or reasons they hate Jews by all means do so, just don't lazily spam curse words that I have to sort through to find actual content and ideas.

 I want a place where I can have actual discussions instead of just a circle jerk of copy pasting the same crap. I didn't leave a left wing propaganda site because I wanted a right wing propaganda site, I would've just went to voat.

parent.body:
I am also a "Reddit refugee" and I did delete my Reddit account and all my comments and posts. So long as Ruqqus retains this clause in their terms:
>Ruqqus reserves the right to remove content that we deem to violate content policy or the terms of service, and to deactivate accounts responsible for such violations.
https://ruqqus.com/help/terms

Then they can still fall into censorship. To be honest, I'm content to use Ruqqus with that clause until they start going the route of Reddit. Maybe then I'll look for an actually distributed, censorship-resistant solution. Until then, I'm content to use the centralized service.
